qas.question: What bird is depicted on the Scottish banknote?
What do the sheep on the Scottish banknote represent?
What form of currency did Canada issue to celebrate Bell in 1997?
In what year did Canada put out a coin to commemorate the Silver Dart?

context: The 150th anniversary of Bell's birth in 1997 was marked by a special issue of commemorative £1 banknotes from the Royal Bank of Scotland. The illustrations on the reverse of the note include Bell's face in profile, his signature, and objects from Bell's life and career: users of the telephone over the ages; an audio wave signal; a diagram of a telephone receiver; geometric shapes from engineering structures; representations of sign language and the phonetic alphabet; the <a0_0>geese<a0_0/> which helped him to understand flight; and the sheep which he studied to understand <a1_0>genetics<a1_0/>. Additionally, the Government of Canada honored Bell in 1997 with a <a2_0>C$100 gold coin<a2_0/>, in tribute also to the 150th anniversary of his birth, and with a silver dollar coin in <a3_0>2009<a3_0/> in honor of the 100th anniversary of flight in Canada. That first flight was made by an airplane designed under Dr. Bell's tutelage, named the Silver Dart. Bell's image, and also those of his many inventions have graced paper money, coinage and postal stamps in numerous countries worldwide for many dozens of years.
